learning_outcomes.description: Explain how chemical principles, including covalent and noncovalent bonding, and the behaviour of acids and bases, govern the structure, stability, and interactions of biomolecules in biological systems.
Describe the function of enzymes and the principles that underpin their properties, control of their activities and their inhibition by pharmacological agents.
Describe the components, properties, chemical principles that underlie the structure and functions of biological membranes and explain how they differ from cell walls.
Compare and contrast the major membrane transport and signalling systems and explain the mechanisms that govern their function.
Explain the fundamental principles of metabolic pathways, including how cells obtain, transform, and store energy through catabolic and anabolic processes.
Understand how metabolic pathways are regulated and integrated, and how disruptions in metabolism can contribute to physiological changes and disease.

Explain the molecular mechanisms of DNA replication, transcription, and translation in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, highlighting both the shared principles and key differences between the two systems.
Describe how gene expression is regulated in prokaryotes and eukaryotes, and how these regulatory mechanisms influence cellular function, heredity, and genome organization.
Discuss the relevance of biochemical principles discussed in this course to veterinary science.

assessments.task_description:
In-semester examination (90 mins) will test comprehension of the lecture material in the first 2 modules.

The exam will be an in-person, timed exam with specified materials permitted.

The exam will comprise true/false questions in which you will be asked to explain and justify your answer; and/or short answer; and/or multiple-choice questions

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: End of Semester examination on modules 3 and 4.
assessments.task_description:
End of semester (final) examination (90 mins) will test comprehension of the lecture material in the second 2 modules.

This will be an in-person, invigilated exam with specified materials permitted.

The exam will comprise true/false questions in which you will be asked to explain and justify your answer; and/or short answer; and/or multiple-choice questions.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

A full list of the topics is on Blackboard. Recordings of all of the lectures will available on Blackboard.

The likely running order will be:

  1. Biological & protein chemistry
  2. Membrane biochemistry
  3. Metabolism
  4. Molecular genetics

This order will be confirmed in the introductory lecture held in week 1.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09
